The force of the bubbles collapsing destroys more than propellers. It destroys concrete dams. In 1983 the Colorado river had record flows and many dams had to use their overflow spillways for the first time. This included Lake Powell's Glen canyon dam. one month into the use of the spillways and one of them turned brown and started throwing truck size boulders into the river. With the lake overflowing they couldn't shut it down and it ran that way for 2 months. They found a hole the size of a 10 story office building in the canyon wall. During the investigation they figured out it was caused by tiny stalagmites on the tunnel floor. When the water came rushing down in a laminar flow it would hit these little protrusions and create a cavitation bubble which then collapsed right at the surface, in nearly the same place, and as it caused damage and pitting the pitting caused more cavitation and the process accelerated until the water was carving out boulders.

Cavitation is also a thing in diesel engine cooling systems. The frequency of the power stroke essentially  bathes the cooling jacket side of the cylinder in Cavitation bubbles. This eventually leads to erosion that eats all the way through the wall of the cylinder. To combat this, we use additives(DCA) to the coolant. The way I understood it, it changed the viscosity/ resonant frequency of the fluid. Thus, reducing the cavitation effect.

An interesting cavitation story is: In 1983 constant heavy rain on top of record snowfall caused a flood of water to rapidly fill the Glen Dam (Grand Canyon). To prevent dam failure and a major flood, spillways were opened. Small imperfections on the spillway walls caused cavitation bubbles. The bubbles floated the same distance and exploded against the wall farther down. Like a jackhammer pounding one spot. This caused pits in the wall, which caused more cavitation. Only larger bubbles, which made larger pits farther down. This happened throughout the tunnel. The last "pit" was over 32 ft and it was predicted that 1000 ft cubed/second of soil concrete and stone was violently ejected from the spillway walls. This incredible video describes the disaster. (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zWVYJ_53dRA)

No no no no NO! Cavitation does not occur because of a low pressure zone behind an object travelling through a fluid! It happens because of Bernoulli's principle of how an increase in the speed of a fluid occurs simultaneously with a decrease in static pressure of the fluid. The faster something travels through water (or other fluid) - be it a bullet, propeller blade, shrimp leg, etc - the less pressure water exerts against it, eventually to the point of vaporization. Therefore cavitation occurs along the surface of the object travelling through liquid - not behind it. In addition, a high pressure zone in front of whatever object definitely has nothing to do with cavitation because liquids are not compressible so there is not high pressure zone in front of bullets and propellers. Physics Girl, you can do better.

A small observation regarding "burst pressure", (ca. 6:45), if I understand correctly, this refers to STATIC pressure over the entire surface, so citing that as proof that the pseudo-scientific-video-guy's "pressure theory" is wrong... is wrong :)
A pressure wave applied to a small area, over a short span of time, could potentially break glass. The smaller the area, and the shorter the time, the less energy it would take to break the glass.
So while cavitation seems to be the main mechanism here, it may just be that other factors, like the small pressure wave that travels through the water, or the one that travels through the glass itself, contribute (to some extent) to the final result.

I actually think the scientific conclusion this video makes about the bottle trick might be slightly incorrect. It seems to me that the shockwave generated by hitting the top of the bottle is what generates the cavitation, not the water getting left behind due to inertia. You hit the top of the bottle, which sends a shockwave through the water, which was actually seen in the footage of this video. Shockwaves in this situation have low pressure zones at the front of the shockwave (from the perspective of standing beside the shockwave, watching it go by), and high pressure zones downstream (pressure is recovered downstream of the shockwave from that perspective). Once the shockwave reaches the bottom of the bottle, that low pressure zone creates the cavitation bubble. I believe the bottle trick works with a completely full bottle (filled with water) with the cap on, if I'm not mistaken. I think this would disprove the "water is left behind slightly due to inertia" theory, given that water can typically be treated as incompressible in this scenario.

It's a common misconception, but water do not start to boil at lower pressure, even it look that way.
If you look at water at an atomic level do you know that every atom consists of mostly empty space and the rest is vacuum. This means that to the water molecule is it surrounded by 100% vacuum and will therefore never "feel" if the air pressure is lower or higher.
What is really going on is the air that are trapped inside the water is no longer compressed so hard by the surrounding air and therefor has the air a chance of to expand and escape. :-)

Yeah, the big reason that trick won't work in carbonated bottles would have to be because of the dissolved gas. Most accurately, a cavitation "bubble" is a pocket of vacuum as the water is pulled apart (by whatever corresponding low pressure event). The energetic release is due to an implosion of that vacuum upon return to a higher pressure state. If there is dissolved gas in the liquid, that gas fills the vacuum and thus you are unable to get an implosion.

Briefly touched on was application in cleaning, and dissolved gas kills useful cavitation. One of the purposes for adding soap to an ultrasonic cleaning tank is it helps encourage the release of any dissolved gases in your cleaning liquid.

On the trick itself, it seems to work best when the bottle is 1/2 to 2/3 full, and when you don't fully cover the top of the bottle when you hit it. I suspect both have to do with reducing pressure on the water. 1/2 to 2/3 full would keep it from bottlenecking at the bottle neck while still having enough water mass to slam down when the cavities collapse. Not covering the bottle would allow air to escape more easily, so also reduce the pressure. Basically putting less down force on the water in both cases, so the bottle moves faster relative to the water.

A tip for improvement of this very interesting lecture: the correct wording would have been “the bottle doesn’t BRING the water with it..” The bottle moves so fast downwards that the air pressure inside is not high enough to maintain the waters position at the bottom of the bottle. When the bottle moves down faster than the natural falling speed of the water, there is a tiny “pulling” force where the water touches the bottle. However this force is low in comparison to the “pushing” force of the air trapped inside. Also, the pulling force is merely acting on the water molecules closest to the bottle walls. ;) ...and people who didn’t listen in physics class at school still tap on ketchup bottles and yet the only thing they do is to move the liquid upwards towards the bottom..... unless they exceed the cavitation limit which they don’t ... 🤣

One very minor correction: I am a retired naval architect who spent many years in research and also in the design group of a major shipyard.  You said that the cavitation on the propeller caused the propeller to slow down.  What happens is that large amounts of cavitation reduce the thrust the propeller is able to produce,  thus limiting the speed the ship can attain.  Virtually all surface ship propellers cavitate some. Current practice,  based on decades of experience,  is that on commercial ships,  cavitation of not more than 5% of the blade area is normally acceptable,  and in service  will not cause significant damage to the propeller over the life of the ship,  but each design must be carefully evaluated using computational fluid dynamics (CFD) and physical model test to ensure that the propeller and ship, when built,  will perform as expected. This phenomenon is also related to the characteristic noise of an electric kettle. It heats the water so rapidly that vapor bubbles are formed at the bottom but the rest of the water is still cool. As the bubble raises by buoyancy it gets to the cold water where it cools rapidly and collapses loudly. Later when all the water is hot enough, the bubbles reach the surface without collapsing and the noise suddenly stops.

I am sorry Diana, but your story about HMS Daring is a bit wrong. At least I have never read that cavitation was her problem. She was originally fitted with two older design locomotive boilers and four-cylinder, triple-expansion piston steam engines, when that was tested she was indeed too slow. Then the boilers were replaced with four (smaller and more efficient) water tube boilers, she exceeded her 26 knot contract speed. But she was never expected to manage 32 kt. See below.
HOWEVER... The story about cavitation was right, just misapplied. The problems with cavitation really became a problem when Charles Parsons started running his steam turbine technology proof vessel SS Turbinia. The single turbine originally fitted ran at high revolutions per second, and resulted in massive cavitation due to the high shaft speed. Parsons replaced the whole engine and propulsion solution with a three shaft system, although the shafts were still turning at the same high speed. To reduce the cavitation, smaller propellors were used to reduce the tip speed, each shaft having three propellors.
The first Royal Navy turbine-driven torpedo boat destroyers all had similar problems, and used a variety of propellor systems to allieviate the cavitation. The best known of those ships was HMS Viper - which at 32 knots, was the fastest military vessel in the world when tested, and therefore the ship you had heard about... but really, Turbinia was THE vessel used for the research.. Viper had four shafts, each with two propellors. By the time a turbines were applied to a ship that was quite large, the direct connected turbines had a large diameter, and so were reasonably efficient in ships like HMS Dreadnought, SS Lusitania and SS Mauretania.
The solution was to slow the shafts down relative to the turbines. That was achieved with reduction gearing, and then improved further with double-reduction gearing. This allowed meeting the hydrodynamic needs separately from the high turbine speeds that are necessary for efficient operation.
The story is quite fascinating if you want to look into it further. Parsons also did research into hull shapes, and that research led to modern transom-sterned planing hulls.
By the way, SS Turbinia, and her turbine power plant, is still to be seen in the Newcastle Maritime Museum in the UK. HMS Viper was not so lucky, she run up onto rocks in a fog.

Very nicely explained! And it is a neat trick. Apart from cavitation bubbles in brains (that is horrifying) and destruction on ships propellers (woah, that is fancy, knowing where these come from) there is one facet you did not really touch on, but that is of high importance for that trick!

Cavitation bubble ARE violent, but where does the energy come from? Ok, your moving hand, but where is it stored then to be released upon collapse of the bubble?
- First, the vacuum of the bubbles provides the space for water, driven by air pressure, to move into (potential energy)
- upon the bubbles collapsing that potential energy is transformed into kinetic energy, the water rushes in! (the whole column has to move)
- when the water column hits the bottom of the bottle the water is slowed down and the kinetic energy converted to, again, potential energy. That is in that case stored in the water by compressing it (it IS slightly compressible), increasing the pressure also in the glass (although you could also think of it as an inelastic shock exerting a force on the bottom, since it is mostly directional)

My point: you NEED enough water to store the energy of your arm! Doing that with only a shallow puddle won't work, because it is ripped apart by air, instead of being pushed by it. But with a little more water there is not so much energy stored in the water (more mass => more potential energy). You have to fill up the bottle rather far! (works good with water, because of high coherent forces between the water molecules! The column doesn't just break apart. Salt water should work better, while we are talking about that; adding intermolecular forces as well as mass!)

And underwater? The sea's surface does not rise to come rushing back in on the propeller (well it might in shallower water, unnoticable by the eye). But since water can be compressed a little, there is a pressure gradient going out into the water, which stores the potential energy, making the water around the bubble rush back in. Again, the energy HAS to be stored in enough water.

+30 year industrial maintenance man and life-long science nerd here, and I can attest that cavitation can be a real and significant problem in a lot more than boat propellers, beer bottles, and brain injuries.
It is a pretty big consideration when specifying pumps, of all types, for any liquid transfer systems.
A pump with too much suction for the liquid (the liquid being transferred, the expected temperature range of the liquid, and the vapor pressure of that liquid within those margins should really be considered) involved will determine the sizing of the pump and the piping leading to and from the pump. Any designed in restriction in either one of those will cause unnecessary cavitation which can spell an early demise for the pump - whether it is a centrifugal pump or a positive displacement pump.
This even comes into play every once in a while in speed controlled hydraulic systems, where restricting the flow of the fluid in some type of fluid filled cylinder without a properly sized orifice for the fluid involved can cause premature failure of the cylinder. In those situations, we typically restric the outflow of the fluid - not the inflow. That way, we keep a higher pressure on both sides which eliminates the possibility of cavitation which can damage the components of the system.

Cavitation is a HUGE concern in fluid dynamics engineering and design. It is nothing to be trifled with or suffered gladly.

So my hypothesis for the carbonated water behaving differently and not causing the bottle bottom to break.
The initial cavitation voids are filled by the CO2 gas coming out of solution (as well as phase changed water). This slows the collapse of cavitation bubbles very significantly as the CO2 has to dissolve back into the water. Longer collapse time means much less of a violent kick.
A great follow up experiment would be to do the same experiment with different amounts of dissolved CO2 to plot how it behaves, and/or film at higher frame rates to allow measuring of the bubble collapse times more accurately.

Cavation happens when the vapor pressure of a fluid is reached. Pumps also experience this same issue. In rocket propulsion when there is a turbopump feeding the propellants into the engine and the vapor pressure of the fluid is reached near the intake of the pump cavation also occurs. In industrial sized pumps cavation occurs because the pump is moving so fast the vapor pressure is reached(similarly to the boat propeller).In centrifugal type pumps there can be what’s called a inducer integrated to raise the pressure of the fluid before it comes in contact with the fast moving impeller so that cavation doesn’t occur. Like mentioned in the video cavation not only reduces efficiency it can also break parts off if the cavation is either aggressive enough or the part is near a cavation producing object(can be seen in the leading blade of the boat propeller in the video)
In conclusion, cavation is cool, except when you are designing something where you definitely don’t want cavation to be.

As an interesting side note, cavitation is also the reason for the noise of the "popping" sound you get when you crack your knuckles - or when your back or neck "cracks" when you move it certain ways, or even when you put some joints under a particular load, eg ankles cracking when you stand up sometimes after kneeling or crouching for a while.

In these cases it's all about a specific, often sudden, pressure drop in the synovial (joint) fluid as the joint is partially tractioned (surfaces pulled apart). Unlike, as with propeller cavitation, the cracking/popping sound occurs as a gas bubble is formed - not as it collapses - and is the reason why a joint can't be re-"popped" for at least a few minutes. This is because the "pop" is the sudden release, or gasseation, of previously dissolved nitrogen from the fluid into a bubble rather than gasseation of the water molecules themselves. To "crack" the joint again it is necessary for the nitrogen to re-dissolve in the joint fluid and attempting too soon will not achieve the required sudden drop in pressure because the gas bubble will expand as you try.

BTW, this process is completely harmless and has no effect on the joint surfaces, in case you were worried! It categorically does NOT increase your odds of developing arthritis.

Cavitation bubbles create an almost pure vacuum in the liquid.  To see how strong that is watch what a vacuum will allow a ping pong to do from one of her earlier videos. The more fluids you have in the bubble the easier it is to blow out the bottom.  Carbonation makes it more difficult because it instantly fills in the cavitation bubbles with CO2 and the bubbles don’t fully collapse. It’s like having some padding so you are not colliding with the fluid on the other side of the bubble.
